deltaq

The deltaq package provides data and interactive tools for exploring the dynamics of COVID-19 outbreaks in Australia during the Delta variant period. It is based on the work by Zachreson et al. (2022), which modelled the efficacy of vaccines and quarantine systems under the Delta variant using simulation techniques.

The package includes:

ðŸ“Š Dataset â€” Simulated quarantine breaches, overseas cases, and arrivals across Australian states between 27 October 2020 and 31 July 2021.
ðŸ’¡ Shiny app â€” An interactive tool that allows users to explore outbreak data, visualize state differences, and simulate quarantine scenarios.
ðŸ“š Documentation â€” Full reproducible examples and reference pages available at
ðŸ‘‰ deltaq documentation site

This package aims to make Zachreson et al.â€™s data and findings more accessible for teaching, research, and interactive communication.

Installation

To install the development version from GitHub:

Option 1 (using remotes):

remotes::install_github(
  "ETC5523-2025/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-ibtesamifaz",
  subdir = "deltaq",
  dependencies = TRUE,
  build_vignettes = FALSE  # speed + avoids pandoc issues
)

Example 

library(deltaq)
head(deltaq_data)
summary(deltaq_data)

You can also launch the interactive Shiny app included in the package: 

deltaq::run_app()

About the data

he dataset provided within deltaq is a cleaned and formatted version of simulation outputs from Zachreson et al.Â (2022), Model-informed risk assessment for COVID-19 quarantine systems under the Delta variant.

It contains daily records of:

  • Simulated quarantine breaches

  • Overseas-acquired cases

  • Traveller arrivals

State identifiers and date range (27 Oct 2020 â€“ 31 Jul 2021)

These data were used to evaluate how well quarantine systems performed against imported Delta infections.

Citation

If you use this package or dataset, please cite:

Zachreson, C., et al.Â (2022). Model-informed risk assessment for COVID-19 quarantine systems under the Delta variant.
